{{Infobox website | name = Yahoo! Kids | logo = | logocaption = | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = | url = [http://kids.yahoo.co.jp kids.yahoo.co.jp] (current)
{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061106215137/http://yahooligans.yahoo.com |date=November 6, 2006 |title=yahooligans.yahoo.com }} | slogan = | commercial = | type = [[Educational]]
[[Entertainment]] | registration = | language = Japanese
English, Korean (until 2013) | num_users = | content_license = | owner = [[Yahoo! Japan]] with characters licensed by [[Sanrio]] | author = | editor = | launch_date = {{Start date and age|1996|4|25}}{{cite web|url=http://yhoo.client.shareholder.com/press/timeline.cfm |title=Yahoo! Inc. - Company Timeline |work=[[Wayback Machine]] |date=2008-07-13 |accessdate=2016-07-20 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080713214826/http://yhoo.client.shareholder.com/press/timeline.cfm |archivedate=2008-07-13 |df= }} (as Yahooligans!) | alexa = | revenue = | current_status = | footnotes = }} [[File:Yahoo Kids.jpg|thumb|Screenshot of Yahoo! Kids website in 2010]] '''Yahoo! Kids''' (known as '''Yahoo!きっず''' in Japan) is a public [[web portal]] provided by [[Yahoo! Japan]] to find [[age appropriateness|age appropriate]] online content for children between the ages of four and twelve. This site was formerly available in English via [[Yahoo!]], where it was known as '''Yahooligans!''' until December 2006, and in Korean via [[Yahoo! Korea]]. The website is used for both educational and entertainment purposes. It was established in March 1996 by [[Yahoo!]] to give children a venue to find appropriate, safe Internet content. Yahoo! Kids is the oldest online search directory for children. Yahoo! Kids and other less popular products were discontinued in English on April 30, 2013 and Korean earlier in the year, allowing the company to redirect its resources to mobile applications. ==History== {{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#FFFFF0 |salign=center |align=right |width=33% |quote=A very special search site for children is Yahooligans which provides a safe environment including a search engine especially designed for children ages 8 to 14. Here is a place for even the very young to experience the web at its best. |source=Susan Wehe of the ''[[Seguin Gazette]]'' on August 4, 1996{{cite news|last=Wehe |first=Susan |date=1996-08-04 |page=11 |title=Internet Beat: Search tools help new Internet users learn ropes |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/876061/the_seguin_gazetteenterprise/ |newspaper=[[Seguin Gazette]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |accessdate=2014-08-17 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuFWxZaF?url=http://www.newspapers.com/clippings/downloadClipping/?id=876061 |archivedate=2014-08-17 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{Open access}}}} Yahoo! Kids, originally known as Yahooligans!,{{cite journal|author=Gunn, Holly |date=2007-07-01 |title=Searching the Web with Search Engines for Children |journal=Teacher Librarian |url=http://visualsearching.pbworks.com/f/Webfor+kids.pdf |accessdate=2010-10-25 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tjuxcNJj?url=http://visualsearching.pbworks.com/f/Webfor+kids.pdf |archivedate=2010-10-25 |deadurl=yes |df= }} was founded in March 1996 by [[Yahoo!]] to provide children with a venue to find appropriate, safe Internet content.{{cite news |title=DIC Toons Online With Yahoo! |author=DeMott, Rick |newspaper=[[Animation World Network]] |date=2004-03-19 |url=http://www.awn.com/news/internet-and-interactive/dic-toons-online-yahoo |accessdate=2010-10-25 }} The website was the oldest online search directory for children.{{cite journal|author=Pack, Thomas |date=2005-12-20 |title=Search Sites for Your Kids |url=https://www.questia.com/magazine/1P3-959214701/search-sites-for-your-kids |publisher=[[Information Today, Inc.]] |volume=22 |issue=11 |accessdate=2014-08-17 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuGB9lUk?url=http://www.questia.com/magazine/1P3-959214701/search-sites-for-your-kids |archivedate=2014-08-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|title=Kids Search Engines |author=Sullivan, Danny |authorlink=Danny Sullivan (technologist) |publisher=[[Search Engine Watch]] |date=2005-04-04 |url=http://searchenginewatch.com/2156191 |accessdate=2010-10-25 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tjpsflsz?url=http://searchenginewatch.com/2156191 |archivedate=2010-10-25 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Harvnb|Whitley|Goodwin|2006|p=xii}} The website's editors stated that Yahoo! Kids was "cool, goofy, fascinating, fun, hysterical, philosophical, surprising, sedate, silly, seismic, popular, obscure, useful, and interesting". In October 1999, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reporter [[Michelle Slatalla]] noted that Yahooligans! was a "heavily trafficked site", with 463,000 visitors accessing the website in August 1999.{{cite news|title=On-Line Help for Inquiring Young Minds |author=Slatalla, Michelle |authorlink=Michelle Slatalla |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=1999-10-07 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/07/technology/library-children-s-search-sites-on-line-help-for-inquiring-young-minds.html |accessdate=2010-10-25 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tjn0F74H?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/07/technology/library-children-s-search-sites-on-line-help-for-inquiring-young-minds.html |archivedate=2010-10-25 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In October 1999, the website received an [[Alexa Internet]] rank of 991 out of 22 million content websites.{{cite news|last=Koenig |first=David |date=1999-10-03 |page=26 |title=Mom runs Internet site from home |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/875950/the_galveston_daily_news/ |newspaper=[[The Daily News (Texas)|The Daily News]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |accessdate=2014-08-17 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuECjAvX?url=http://www.newspapers.com/clippings/downloadClipping/?id=875950 |archivedate=2014-08-17 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{Open access}} In 2004, Yahoo! entered into a partnership with [[DIC Entertainment]] to establish Yahooligans! TV, which gave users access to DIC's 3,000 hours of animated [[Children's television series|children programs]]. DIC Entertainment president Brad Brooks stated that the partnership "offer[ed] advertisers a cross platform purchase". Yahoo! sold the ads and the revenue from the commercials was split between the two companies.{{cite news|title=DIC Ent. teams for Yahooligans! |author=Bond, Paul |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=2004-03-18 |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/services/amusement-recreation-services/4719599-1.html |accessdate=2010-10-25 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tjolUYzP?url=http://www.allbusiness.com/services/amusement-recreation-services/4719599-1.html |archivedate=2010-10-25 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Content== The website was used for both educational and entertainment purposes.{{cite news|title=Nick, Yahooligans Offer Kid-Friendly Content |author=Jones, Karen |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2000-11-02 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/nov/02/news/tt-45705/2 |accessdate=2010-10-25 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tjn2pbqD?url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/nov/02/news/tt-45705/2 |archivedate=2010-10-25 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The Yahoo! Kids' portal had directories such as "Around the World", "Arts & Entertainment", "Computers & Games", "School Bell", "Science & Nature", and "Sports & Recreation". Under the directory "School Bell", the category "Homework Answers" allowed children to access websites pertaining to school subjects such as geography, history, and math.{{cite news |title=The Goods; 'Yahooligans!' Helps Keep Junior Net Surfers on Safe Turf |author=Colker, David |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=1996-03-26 }} Under "Around the World", children could learn about countries, politics, and history.{{cite news|last=Irick |first=Amy |date=1998-01-19 |page=6 |title=Yahooligans! |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/875731/the_kokomo_tribune/ |newspaper=[[Kokomo Tribune]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |accessdate=2014-08-17 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuBculyQ?url=http://www.newspapers.com/clippings/downloadClipping/?id=875731 |archivedate=2014-08-17 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{Open access}} The "Art Soup" directory taught children about museums and drama, and the "Scoop" let them look at comics and newspapers. It had an [[Associated Press]] section to let children read age-appropriate articles.{{cite news|last=Smathers |first=John |date=2002-06-23 |page=37 |title=When kids get bored, link them up with a computer |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/876332/indiana_gazette/ |newspaper=[[Indiana Gazette]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |accessdate=2014-08-18 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuIP0nyB?url=http://www.newspapers.com/clippings/downloadClipping/?id=876332 |archivedate=2014-08-18 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{Open access}} The parents' section of the website contained advice about being safe while browsing the Internet and links to services that "block and filter websites".{{cite news|last=Irick |first=Amy |date=1999-08-15 |page=20 |title=Internet isn't just for fun |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/875637/the_kokomo_tribune/ |newspaper=[[Kokomo Tribune]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |accessdate=2014-08-17 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuANkQhM?url=http://www.newspapers.com/clippings/downloadClipping/?id=875637 |archivedate=2014-08-17 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{Open access}} The teachers' section contained lesson plans for "planning, implementing and assessing integrated units". It was separated into three ranks: kindergarten through second grade, third through fifth grade, and sixth to eighth grade. Educational professionals and former teachers screened each website listed in Yahooligans.{{cite news|last=Murphy |first=Ann Pleshette |date=2006-10-08 |page=50 |title=Safeguard your kids' Web surfing |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/876205/the_salina_journal/ |newspaper=[[The Salina Journal]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |accessdate=2014-08-18 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuHEtoOR?url=http://www.newspapers.com/clippings/downloadClipping/?id=876205 |archivedate=2014-08-18 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{Open access}} The homepage displayed links to games, jokes, news, and sports. For the latter three, the content was crafted for those younger than 12. Yahooligans! directed viewers to child-friendly websites like those from [[Smithsonian Institution]] and [[Louvre]]. It adopted the persona of [[Bill Clinton]]'s pet cat, [[Socks (cat)|Socks]], to introduce viewers to the [[White House]]'s website in 1995.{{cite news|last=Flynn |first=Laurie J. |date=1997-06-05 |title=Hand in Small Hand Around the Internet |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/garden/hand-in-small-hand-around-the-internet.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2014-08-17 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuDPsA94?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/garden/hand-in-small-hand-around-the-internet.html |archivedate=2014-08-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Games provided on the Yahoo! Kids website included [[Chinese checkers]], [[Go Fish]], and [[English draughts|Checkers]]. Age-appropriate offsite games were also accessible via the links under the "games" tab. The website offered an [[instant messaging]] gadget that allows children to participate in live chats with notable people, such as [[Bill Clinton]], [[J. K. Rowling]], and [[Bill Nye|Bill Nye the Science Guy]]. In March 2011, Yahoo! Kids partnered with the TV series [[Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008 TV series)|Star Wars: The Clone Wars]] near the season's finale to have children pose questions to Chewbacca. Question submissions were posted on [[SurveyMonkey]], and Yahoo! Kids posted Chewbacca's answers on March 28.{{cite news|title=Ask Chewbacca a Question at Yahoo! Kids |author=Jones, Jason B. |url=https://www.wired.com/geekdad/2011/03/ask-chewbacca-a-question-at-yahoo-kids/ |publisher=[[Wired (website)|Wired News]] |date=2011-03-13 |accessdate=2012-05-11 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67ak1osIC?url=http://www.wired.com/geekdad/2011/03/ask-chewbacca-a-question-at-yahoo-kids/ |archivedate=2012-05-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The approximately three-minute long video consisted of Chewbacca pantomiming responses to queries such as "How do you deal with all that hair?"{{cite news|title=Chewie Answers Clone Wars Questions at Yahoo! Kids |author=Jones, Jason B. |url=https://www.wired.com/geekdad/2011/03/chewie-answers-clone-wars-questions-at-yahoo-kids/ |publisher=[[Wired (website)|Wired News]] |date=2011-03-28 |accessdate=2012-05-11 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67ak3bfwj?url=http://www.wired.com/geekdad/2011/03/chewie-answers-clone-wars-questions-at-yahoo-kids/ |archivedate=2012-05-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Reviews== In August 1996, Greg Mefford of ''The Galveston Daily News'' (later renamed to ''[[The Daily News (Texas)|The Daily News]]'') stated that Yahooligans is "as much fun as it is educational, with links to darn near everything".{{cite news|last=Mefford |first=Greg |date=1996-08-04 |page=22 |title=Educational aids aplenty are online |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/876408/the_galveston_daily_news/ |newspaper=[[The Daily News (Texas)|The Daily News]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |accessdate=2014-08-18 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuJ8MUVL?url=http://www.newspapers.com/clippings/downloadClipping/?id=876408 |archivedate=2014-08-18 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{Open access}} ''[[Kokomo Tribune]]'' columnist Amy Irick wrote in January 1998 that Yahooligans! was a "great alternative to the Yahoo! search engine for younger computer users". In August 1999, Irick said that Yahooligans! was "very user friendly, just like its parent Yahoo!" and that its teachers' guide is a "must see for teachers". ''[[Indiana Gazette]]''{{'}}s John Smathers wrote in June 2002, "I can't mention kids sites without mentioning Yahooligans.com", praising the website as a "great tool to teach kids more about Internet surfing". In June 2005, reviewer Gail Junion-Metz of the ''[[School Library Journal]]'' praised Yahooligans! Games, writing that it is "[o]ne of the best spots to find kid-appropriate games that don't require downloads".{{cite journal |author=Junion-Metz, Gail |date=June 2005 |title=Yahooligans! Games (Review of yahooligans.yahoo.com) |journal=[[School Library Journal]] |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |volume=51 |issue=6 |page=68 }} In a September 1998 review of the website, John Hilvert and Linda Bruce of ''PC User'' (now named ''[[TechLife]]'') wrote that "Yahooligans is one of the best specialized engines, particularly for homework answers."{{cite journal |author=Hilvert, John |author2=Bruce, Linda |date=September 1998 |title=Search engines compared |journal=[[PC User]] |volume=10 |issue=9 |page=102 }} In July 2007, reviewer Holly Gunn of ''Teacher Librarian'' praised Yahoo! Kids for its helpful, comprehensible results but criticized it for having an interface filled with too many ads and that was "too busy and filled with too many diversions. Useful material is buried amidst entertainment". ==Closure== Yahoo! Kids closed on April 30, 2013.{{cite news|title=Yahoo Kids, Deals, More Getting the Boot |author=Albanesius, Chloe |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2417977,00.asp |newspaper=[[PC Magazine]] |date=2013-04-19 |accessdate=2013-05-20 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GlgOrCs0?url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2417977,00.asp |archivedate=2013-05-21 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In February 2013, Yahoo! CEO [[Marissa Mayer]] told an investor conference that the company aimed to slash their approximately 60–75 products to about 12, increasing their attention on mobile device applications.{{cite news|title=Yahoo Trims Product Lineup as Mayer Sharpens Focus on Mobile |author=MacMillan, Douglas |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-04-19/yahoo-trims-product-lineup-as-mayer-sharpens-focus-on-mobile.html |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg.com]] |date=2013-04-19 |accessdate=2013-05-20 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GlhOzUcH?url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-04-19/yahoo-trims-product-lineup-as-mayer-sharpens-focus-on-mobile.html |archivedate=2013-05-21 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In an April 19, 2013, blog post announcing Yahoo! Kids' closure, Yahoo! Executive Vice president of Platforms Jay Rossiter wrote:
[W]e want to bring you experiences that inspire and entertain you every day. That means taking a hard look at all of our products to make sure they are still central to your daily habits. As part of that ongoing effort, today we are shutting down a few more products.{{cite news|title=Sharpening our focus – to bring you new Yahoo! products |author=Rossiter, Jay |url=http://yodel.yahoo.com/blogs/general/sharpening-focus-bring-yahoo-products-010032874.html |newspaper= |accessdate=2013-05-20 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Glj3v7U5?url=http://yodel.yahoo.com/blogs/general/sharpening-focus-bring-yahoo-products-010032874.html |archivedate=2013-05-21 |deadurl=yes |df= }}
He said that Yahoo! would redirect those resources to newer products like email and weather mobile applications. Rossiter wrote that Yahoo!'s "youngest users" could continue using the company's services. Children younger than 13 could create a Yahoo! account through Yahoo!'s Family Accounts program. Young users could also find age-appropriate movies through the "Family Movies" section of Yahoo! Movies. ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|30em}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |title=99 Jumpstarts for Kids' Science Research |last=Whitley |first=Peggy |author2=Goodwin, Susan Williams |year=2006 |publisher=Libraries Unlimited |location=Westport, Connecticut |isbn=1-59158-261-X |ref=CITEREFWhitleyGoodwin2006 }} {{refend}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |title=Yahooligans!: The Ultimate 2003 Kids Passport to the Web |last=Newquist |first=Trini |year=2002 |publisher=San Val |isbn=0-613-87258-4 }} * {{cite book |title=Yahooligans!: Way Cool Web Sites |authors=Raucci, Richard; Crane, Elizabeth; [[David Filo|Filo, David]]; [[Jerry Yang (entrepreneur)|Yang, Jerry]] |year=2002 |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]] |location=Foster City, California |isbn=0-7645-7002-1 }} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061106215137/http://yahooligans.yahoo.com/ Yahooligans!] on November 6, 2006 (from the [[Internet Archive]]'s [[Wayback Machine]]) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130426200557/http://kids.yahoo.com/ Yahoo! Kids] on April 26, 2013 (from the [[Internet Archive]]'s [[Wayback Machine]]) * [http://kids.yahoo.co.jp/ Yahoo! Kids Japan] {{Ja icon}} {{SoftBank}} {{Yahoo! Inc.}} [[Category:Discontinued Yahoo! services|Kids]] [[Category:Web directories]] [[Category:Children's websites]] [[Category:Educational websites]] [[Category:Products introduced in 1996]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1996]] [[Category:Internet properties disestablished in 2013]] [[Category:Yahoo! international|Japan]] [[Category:Internet in Japan]] [[Category:Japanese websites]] [[Category:Japanese-language websites]] [[Category:SoftBank]]

'''Zoe Dumitrescu-Bușulenga''' (August 20, 1920 – May 5, 2006) was a [[Romania]]n comparatist and essayist. A native of the national capital [[Bucharest]], she was educated at [[University of Bucharest|its main university]], going on to become a professor there. Together with a focus on interdisciplinary studies, she was noted for devoting several studies to [[Mihail Eminescu]]. Meanwhile, Dumitrescu was a dignitary of the [[Romanian Communist Party]]. Following the [[Romanian Revolution]], after several years spent in Rome, she retired to a monastery.
==Biography== ===Education and academic career=== Born in [[Bucharest]], her parents were Nicolae Dumitrescu, a jurist, and his wife Maria (''née'' Apostol).<ref name="sasu"/> In her native city, she attended primary school (1927–1931) and the Central School for Girls (1931–1939).<ref name="dobre"/> An early lover of music, she was unable to pursue a career in that field due to medical reasons.<ref name="alex"/> Enrolling in the [[University of Bucharest]], she studied law from 1939 to 1943 and literature from 1944 to 1948, and earned a doctorate in 1970. Also, from 1947 to 1948, around the time a [[Communist Romania|communist regime]] was established in her country, she went to the Soviet Union to attend the [[N. A. Dobrolyubova State Linguistic University of Nizhny Novgorod|Gorky Pedagogical Institute]].<ref name="dobre">{{ro icon}} Florica Dobre (ed.), ''Membrii C. C. al P. C. R.: 1945-1989'', p. 245. Bucharest: Editura Enciclopedică, 2004. {{ISBN|973-45-0486-X}}</ref> Dumitrescu worked as an editor at Editura de Stat from 1948 to 1949, and at Editura pentru Literatură until 1957. Hired as teaching assistant at her alma mater in 1949, she rose to assistant professor in 1951, associate professor in 1963, full professor in 1971 and began chairing the department of universal and comparative literature in 1975.<ref name="dobre"/> Critic [[Alex. Ștefănescu]], a former student, recalled her courses as being "impressive in their erudition and solemnity, and through a veneration of humanist values visibly at odds with the proletarian egalitarianism promoted by the communist regime".<ref name="alex"/>
Having been a researcher there until 1957, she rose to director of the George Călinescu Institute of Literary History and Theory in 1973. She was admitted to the [[Romanian Writers' Union]] in 1963. From 1970 to 1982, she served as vice president of the Social and Political Sciences Academy.<ref name="dobre"/> She was elected a corresponding member of the [[Romanian Academy]] in 1974. In 1975, she became president of the Romanian National Committee for Comparative Literature, from 1973 to 1979 was on the executive board of the [[International Comparative Literature Association]], and in 1972 was visiting professor at the [[University of Amsterdam]].<ref name="sasu"/> Dumitrescu's rapid ascent in academia drew the ire of [[Elena Ceaușescu]], who eventually decided to halt her progress.<ref name="alex"/> She directed two magazines, ''Synthesis'' and ''Revista de istorie și teoria literară''. A comparatist and critic in the Anglo-German mould, her interests included [[interdisciplinarity]] and [[philosophy of culture]]. Among her books were ''Renașterea: Umanismul și dialogul artelor'' (1971), ''Valori și echivalențe umanistice'' (1973), ''Periplu umanistic'' (1980) and ''Itinerarii prin cultură'' (1982). Dumitrescu also initiated and coordinated several syntheses of literary history for the institute she led.<ref name="sasu">{{ro icon}} Aurel Sasu (ed.), ''Dicționarul biografic al literaturii române'', vol. I, p. 539. Pitești: Editura Paralela 45, 2004. {{ISBN|973-697-758-7}}</ref> Four books she published between 1964 and 1989 closely analyze the works of poet [[Mihail Eminescu]].<ref name="maica"/> A gifted communicator, she spoke widely: before students, in conference halls and on radio and television, emerging as a public intellectual.<ref name="alex"/>
===Political involvement, later years and legacy=== Dumitrescu joined the [[Romanian Communist Party]] in 1966, the year after [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]] came to power. She was a member of the party's central committee from August 1969 to November 1974.<ref name="dobre"/> She served two terms in the [[Great National Assembly]], representing Bucharest districts both times: from 1975 to 1980 and from 1980 to 1985. She was awarded the Order of 23 August, fourth class; this was followed in 1971 by the Cultural Merit Order, second class; and by the special prize of the Writers' Union in 1986 and 1989. She was granted the [[Order of Cyril and Methodius]] by the [[People's Republic of Bulgaria]] in 1977, and the following year became a commander of the [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic]]. She took the [[Herder Prize]] in 1988.<ref name="dobre"/> In 1990, following the [[Romanian Revolution]], she was elevated to titular membership of the Romanian Academy.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.acad.ro/bdar/armembriLit.php?vidT=D Membrii Academiei Române din 1866 până în prezent] at the Romanian Academy site</ref> From 1991 to 1997, she headed the ''[[Accademia di Romania]]'' in Rome.<ref>{{ro icon}} Florin Toma, [http://www.viataromaneasca.eu/arhiva/103_viata-romaneasca-12-2015/129_semnal/2306_accademia-di-romania-la-93-de-ani.html "Accademia di Romania, la 93 de ani"], in ''Viața Românească'', nr. 12/2015</ref>
Late in life, beginning around 2000, she spent most of her time at the [[Romanian Orthodox]] [[Văratec Monastery]] and ultimately took the vows of a nun, adopting the name Benedicta.<ref name="alex"/><ref name="maica"/> She had been introduced to the monastery by Valeria, the widow of writer [[Mihail Sadoveanu]], who invited her to spend summers there.<ref name="alex">{{ro icon}} Alex. Ștefănescu, [http://www.romlit.ro/ce_urt_ne-am_purtat_cu_zoe_dumitrescu-buulenga "Ce urât ne-am purtat cu Zoe Dumitrescu-Bușulenga!"], in ''România Literară'', nr. 19/2006</ref><ref name="maica">{{ro icon}} Mădălin Sofronie, [http://adevarul.ro/locale/slobozia/cum-s-a-transformat-criticul-literar-zoe-dumitrescu-busulenga-maica-benedicta-cea-deslusit-misterele-credintei-dumnezeu-1_55cf1a74f5eaafab2c8a2503/index.html "Cum s-a transformat criticul literar Zoe Dumitrescu-Bușulenga în maica Benedicta"], in ''Adevărul'', August 16, 2015</ref> Dumitrescu was herself a widow,<ref>{{ro icon}} Alex. Ștefănescu, [http://www.evz.ro/zoe-dumitrescu-busulenga-a-spus-nu-istoriile-lui-alex-stefanescu.html "Zoe Dumitrescu-Bușulenga a spus NU"], in ''Evenimentul Zilei'', January 8, 2016</ref> having married at age 29, and had no children.<ref>{{ro icon}} Teodora Stanciu, [http://www.romlit.ro/zoe_dumitrescu-buulengaaveam_o_grdin_splendid_n_spatele_casei._acolo_am_trit_pn_la_29_de_ani. "Zoe Dumitrescu-Bușulenga:'Aveam o grădină splendidă în spatele casei. Acolo am trăit până la 29 de ani.'"], in ''România Literară'', nr. 34/2007</ref> She died in [[Iași]] and was buried at [[Putna Monastery]].<ref name="sasu"/> Writing shortly after her death, Ștefănescu claimed that her rapprochement with the regime was motivated by a desire to be left alone, permitted to teach the humanities at home and assert the importance of Romanian culture abroad. He lamented that this stance drew opprobrium in the post-communist period, both from "maniacal vigilantes bereft of a feeling for nuance" and from "poorly educated youths of the sort who deface statues with paint".<ref name="alex"/>
